title-group.article-title: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails (Caenogastropoda: Truncatelloidea: Hydrobiidae) from Morocco

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails ( Caenogastropoda : Truncatelloidea : Hydrobiidae ) from Morocco
MOHAMED GHAMIZI 1,5 , ANDRZEJ FALNIOWSKI 2,6 , ABDERRAZZAQ BOUDELLAH 1,7 , SEBASTIAN HOFMAN 3 , ASSIA EL RHARRAS 1,8 , NABILA ASSAD 1,9 , SOUMIA MOUTAOUAKIL 1,10 & ALEKSANDRA JASZCZYŃSKA 2,4*

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Stygobiont and crenobiont minute gastropods representing the family Hydrobiidae ( Caenogastropoda : Truncatelloidea ), characterized by the valvatoid low-spired shell, were collected from one spring and four wells in Bouregreg region, NW Morocco . The shells were photographed and measured; shell biometry is illustrated with principal component analysis. Penes were illustrated and described. Mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit 1 (COI) and 16S rRNA, as well as nuclear 18S rRNA sequences were used to infer the phylogeny. The snails represented two genera, both new to science. Their closest relatives were taxa from the Iberian Peninsula, the rough molecular estimate of the time of divergence between these Moroccan and Iberian genera coincided with the Pliocene Flooding, which restored the Strait of Gibraltar to connect the Mediterranean Basin with Atlantic Ocean.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Key words: mtDNA , cytochrome oxidase , nuclear 18 S , shell , penes , stygobiont , molecular phylogeny , Pliocene Flooding

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The Truncatelloidea are globally distributed and the most species-rich group of freshwater gastropods, minute in size, mostly inhabiting springs and subterranean waters, and still poorly studied. Morphology alone is often insufficient (
,
) for species delineation. Molecular data are helpful in species discrimination as well as the reconstruction of phylogenetic relationships, but are still unavailable for most of the species, and too few loci have been studied so far. The Moroccan Truncatelloidea , mostly Hydrobiidae , are recently extensively studied (e.g.
,
,
,
,
,
,
, 2022a, b) and some studies deal with the relationships between the NW African and Iberian fauna (e.g.
,
). Perhaps the most poorly studied truncatelloid gastropods are the ones with valvatoid, low-spired shells, often less than 1 mm high.

Considering the geological history of the region, phylogenetic relationships of the Moroccan and Iberian Hydrobiidae are most probable. Thus, the Iberian Hydrobiidae , rather well studied (e.g.
,
,
,
) are a priority to compare with the Moroccan Hydrobiidae . Fortunately, there are also molecular data for these gastropods. This paper presents their shells, penes and molecularly based phylogenetic relationships of valvatoid hydrobiid gastropods collected from Morocco .

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Bouregreg watershed in Morocco extends over an area of approximately 9,800 km 2 , is limited to the North-East by the Sebou basin, to the South by that of Oum-Er-Rbia, to the South- West by the basins of the coastal rivers (Cherrat, Nefifikh and Mellah) and opens towards the West onto the Atlantic Ocean. Elliptical in shape, it is drained by four main hydrographic arteries, each draining an area of 4,000 km ² (Oued Bouregreg), 3,600 km ² (Oued Grou), 1,900 km ² (Oued Krifla) and 150 km ² (Oued Akrech). The climate is semi-arid, with an average annual temperature of 15°–18°C in coastal areas and 15°–17°C in mountainous areas. Average annual precipitation is around 400 mm in coastal areas and 760 mm near the village of Oulmes in the mountains to the west of the basin. The prospected sites include 13 river samples (R), 25 wells (P) and 4 springs (S) distributed in the Bouregreg basin ( Fig. 1 ). Five sites (4 wells and 1 spring) provided the material described in this article ( Table 1 , Figs. 2–3 ).

The snails were collected from wells by phreatobiological net (
), by filtering subterranean water through a nylon net of 200 µm mesh and sieving mud and sediment, and from springs by cleaning the small pebbles from the sediment over a nylon net of 200 µm mesh. The snails were fixed in 80% analytically pure ethanol and kept in -20 oC in refrigerator. The parameters as temperature, pH, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, and total dissolved solids (TDS) of the water were measured in situ with a multi-parameter probe HI 98194. The measured parameters are given in Table 2 .

For molecular analysis, DNA was extracted from whole specimens; tissues were hydrated in TE buffer (3 × 10 min); then, total genomic DNA was extracted with the SHERLOCK extraction kit (A&A Biotechnology), and the final product was dissolved in 20 μL of tris-EDTA (TE) buffer. The extracted DNA was stored at −80 °C at the Department of Malacology, Institute of Zoology and Biomedical Research, Jagiellonian University in Kraków ( Poland ). Mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI), 16S ribosomal RNA (16S) and 18S ribosomal RNA (18S) were sequenced. Details of PCR conditions, primers used, and sequencing were given by Szarowska et al . (2016).

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Five specimens , collected at four wells and the source of Bouregreg River, were sequenced ( Fig. 4 ) for COI (479 bp, GenBank accession numbers PP079487–PP079491), 16S (400 bp, GenBank accession numbers PP081621– PP081625) and 18S (286 bp, GenBank accession numbers PP081646–PP081650). For COI, the test for the substitution saturation analysis showed an ISS value 0.75, significantly smaller than the critical ISS value (0.96), indicating that sequences are not saturated and thus useful in phylogenetic reconstruction. The topologies of the resulting phylograms were identical in both the ML and BI phylogram analyses; thus, we present the phylogram computed with RAxML ( Fig. 4 ). They represented two distinct species, each of them representing a distinct genus, since the p-distance was 0.133, typical of the intergeneric relationships within the Hydrobiidae , and in the molecular tree ( Fig. 2 ) there were other genera between them. The results of all three techniques of species delimitation were identical and clearly indicated the distinctness of the two obtained mOTUs ( Fig. 2 ). The MDCs of both new genera were obtained by comparing them with all the sequences belonging to the clade marked grey on Fig. 4 . Principal component analysis, computed for four characters and for 19 individuals, showed PC1 – eigenvalue: 4.02, variability explained and cumulative: 59.1%, PC2 – eigenvalue: 2.43, variability explained: 23.5%, cumulative: 82.6% and PC3 – eigenvalue: 1.15, variability explained: 15.9%, cumulative: 98.5%. Genetic differences are poorly supported by morphological differences, some differences existed for PC3, where the main component was the b parameter ( Fig. 6 ), indicating that
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
have wider shells. The Mann–Whitney U test did not confirm this relationship (Z = 1.939, P=0.0524).

sec.title: Orphanage

sec.title: Class GASTROPODA Cuvier, 1795 Subclass CAENOGASTROPODA Cox, 1960

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023

mixed-citation.named-content: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails (Caenogastropoda: Truncatelloidea: Hydrobiidae) from Morocco

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Genus
Maroccoarganiella Ghamizi et Falniowski
, gen. nov.
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: E6A83AB5-376C-4982-96A9-E19A2A82EE73

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Type species.
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
by monophyly.

Diagnosis. Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with hardly visible spire and circular aperture below the half of height of body whorl, neither eyes nor pigment, flat and massive, broad penis with broad and not prominent outgrowth on its right side. Molecular Diagnostic Characters for COI: asymmetric: 81(C), 369(C).

Etymology. Both the shell habitus and penis morphology resemble Italian
Arganiella pescei Giusti et Pezzoli, 1980
.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023

mixed-citation.named-content: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails (Caenogastropoda: Truncatelloidea: Hydrobiidae) from Morocco

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Maroccoarganiella touarguii Ghamizi et Falniowski
, sp. nov.

tp:treatment-sec.p: urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: A1793C4D-C60C-4DC5-9BB0-0229A8BBD8CD
GenBank no. for COI: PP079487–PP079489

Diagnosis. Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with hardly visible spire and circular aperture below the half of height of body whorl, neither eyes nor pigment, flat and massive, broad penis with broad and not prominent outgrowth on its right side.

Individual shell height shell breadth aperture height aperture breadth
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
holotype 0.54 1.30 0.54 0.56 A131 0.66 1.23 0.55 0.56 A132 0.69 1.19 0.49 0.51 A133 0.51 1.12 0.46 0.46 P2B2_05 0.50 1.25 0.47 0.53 P3B2_03 0.64 1.35 0.49 0.51 P3B2_04 0.63 1.34 0.53 0.53 P3B2_05 0.60 1.22 0.50 0.51 Mean 0.60 1.25 0.50 0.52 Standard Deviation 0.07 0.08 0.03 0.03 Minimum 0.50 1.12 0.46 0.46 Maximum 0.69 1.35 0.55 0.56
Maroccohoratia bouregreggensis
holotype 0.58 1.17 0.52 0.49 A130 0.57 0.99 0.49 0.45 S3B2-morphology 0.67 1.14 0.51 0.49 Mean 0.61 1.10 0.51 0.48 Standard Deviation 0.06 0.10 0.02 0.02 Minimum 0.57 0.99 0.49 0.45 Maximum 0.67 1.17 0.52 0.49
Etymology. The species name dedicated to a deceased colleague that participated in the field collection: Professor Touargui member of AESVT Khemisset.

Differential diagnosis. The shell and the penis resemble the ones of Italian
Arganiella pescei Giusti et Pezzoli, 1980
( Giusti & Pezzoli 1980 ,
Delicado et al . 2021
). The Moroccan
Ainiella Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2022
(
Taybi et al . 2022c
), and
Rifia yacoubii Ghamizi, 2020
differ in the outgrowth on the left side of the penis ( Ghamizi 2020 ), absent in
Maroccoarganiella
.
Islamia Radoman, 1973
with its bi-lobed penis ( Radoman 1973 ) is evidently different. From among the Iberian valvatiform
Hydrobiidae (
Delicado et al . 2019
)
similar shell can be found in
Iberhoratia Arconada et Ramos, 2007
(
Arconada et al . 2007
), but the penis in
Iberhoratia
has conspicuous outgrowth on its left side.Another Iberian valvatoid genus:
Corbellaria Callot-Girardi et Boeters, 2012
has similar shell but its penis also bears prominent outgrowth (
Ramos et al . 2000
,
Boeters et al . 2019
). The Moroccan genera with the penis without outgrowth:
Ifrania Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) and
Pikasia Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2021
(
Taybi et al . 2021
) have shells with lower and less circular aperture, and their penes do not resemble the broad and flat one of
Maroccoarganiella
. Moroccan
Fessia Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) has the shell with much higher spire, lower and somewhat oval aperture, and more slender penis; also the eyes and pigmentation of the body is characteristic of
Fessia Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
), but not of
Maroccoarganiella
, although this troglomorphic adaptation is facultative and easily gained or lost ( Culver & Pipan 2009 ). In
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
the shell is strikingly different than in
Maroccoarganiella
, globular with higher spire, some of the paratypes illustrated by
Mabrouki et al . (2023)
could be classified rather as trochiform, not valvatiform following Hershler & Ponder (1998) . In
Menzella timedrinensis
there are eyes and pigmentation, also on the penis, which is bent, unlike our
Maroccoarganiella
.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023

mixed-citation.named-content: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails (Caenogastropoda: Truncatelloidea: Hydrobiidae) from Morocco

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Genus
Maroccohoratia Ghamizi et Falniowski
, gen. nov.

tp:treatment-sec.p: urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: 492B06E4-4DC9-47E6-96BC-BB1D16D38E8B

Type species.
Maroccohoratia bouregregensis
by monophyly.

Diagnosis. Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with tiny but visible spire and oval aperture expanded to 2 / 3 of body whorl height, eyes present but unpigmented, penis bent, triangular, sharpening abruptly, with broad slightly marked outgrowth on its right side. Molecular Diagnostic Characters for COI: binary: 262(C), 348(G); asymmetric: 75(C), 141(C).

Etymology. The name derived from Morocco and the Iberian sister clade
Iberhoratia Arconada et Ramos, 2007
.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023

mixed-citation.named-content: Two new genera and species of the valvatiform hydrobiid snails (Caenogastropoda: Truncatelloidea: Hydrobiidae) from Morocco

tp:treatment-sec.p: urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: 36CA6651-89E1-4C6E-AC35-94115249D22B
GenBank no. for COI: PP079490–PP079491

Diagnosis . Minute valvatiform hydrobiid gastropod with tiny but well visible spire and oval aperture expanded to 2 / 3 of body whorl height, eyes present but unpigmented, penis bent, triangular, sharpening abruptly, with broad slightly marked outgrowth on its right side.
Etymology . The name derived from the name of the basin where the species was collected: basin Bouregreg in Morocco .

Differential diagnosis. The Moroccan
Ainiella Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2022
(
Taybi et al . 2022c
), and
Rifia yacoubii Ghamizi, 2020
differ in the outgrowth on the left side of the penis, absent in this new genus.
Islamia Radoman, 1973
with its bi-lobed penis is evidently different. From among the Iberian valvatiform
Hydrobiidae (
Delicado et al . 2019
)
similar shell can be found in
Spathogyna fezi ( Altimira, 1960 )
. The genus
Spathogyna Arconada et Ramos, 2002
, however, is characterised by the penis with distinct outgrowth on its left side ( Arconada & Ramos 2002 ).
Pikasia Taybi, Glöer et Mabrouki, 2021
have shells with lower aperture and massive body whorl (
Taybi et al . 2021
),
Fessia Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) have shells with circular, not oval and lower aperture, body whorl growing slowly, higher and broader spire, and penis with no outgrowth on its right side. The shell of
Ifrania Glöer, Mabrouki et Taybi, 2020
(
Glöer et al . 2020b
) differs in much lower aperture, broader spire not directed left, and much more slender penis without the outgrowth on its right side. In
Menzella timedrinensis Mabrouki, Glöer et Taybi, 2023
, as already pointed above, the shell is strikingly different, globular with higher spire, some of the paratypes illustrated by
Mabrouki et al . (2023)
could be classified rather as trochiform, not valvatiform following Hershler & Ponder (1998) . In
Menzella timedrinensis
there are eyes and pigmentation, also on the penis, which is bent, the penis is different in shape and without the outgrowth on its right side, characteristic of our
Maroccohoratia .

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Considering the geographic distribution of the Hydrobiidae , restricted to the SW part of the Palearctic, and some territories in N America and N Africa (
), the obvious origin of the Moroccan Hydrobiidae should be West Europe, especially the Iberian Peninsula. Our COI-based molecular phylogram is not well supported, thus exact dating cannot be done. However, some rough estimates are still possible. The K2P distances for COI were 0.136 between
Maroccoarganiella touarguii
and
Aretiana wolfi
, and 0.131 between
Maroccohoratia bouregregensis
and
Iberohoratia morenoi
, mean 0.133. This, applying the estimates of
,
,
), may reflect the time 5.19 Mya (million years ago), thus slightly less than 5.33 ending the Messinian Salinity Crisis (
) thus destroying the bridge between the Iberian Peninsula and North Africa. The differences seem to confirm the divergence starting after geographic isolation but this conclusion is tentative considering the weakness of our dating estimates

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: This study was carried out within the framework of the CEPF Project “Improving knowledge on rare and threatened species in the Bouregreg watershed, Morocco ” which has among its objectives to improve knowledge on freshwater biodiversity and highlight the importance freshwater ecosystem services. The MHNM Authors thank the Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund for the financial support (CEPF grant n.111540) and AESVT Khemisset for their assistance. The study was supported by the grant N18/DBS/000012, from the Institute of Zoology and Biomedical Research, Jagiellonian University.
